awd_titl_txt: Travel: Junior travel support for the 2024 World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will fund 25 travel awards for US-based junior researchers attending the 2024 ISBA (International Society for Bayesian Analysis) World Meeting, to be held in Venice, Italy from 1-7 July 2024. The meeting's website is https://www.unive.it/web/en/2208/home. The ISBA World Meetings are the largest conferences in Bayesian statistics, attracting attendees from all around the world. The travel awards, averaging $800 per person, will partially offset the cost of travelling to Venice from the US, helping PhD students and other junior researchers to participate in the meeting. The selection committee will prioritize funding female researchers and members of minority groups underrepresented in the field.
 
The 2024 ISBA World Meeting will feature keynote talks, invited and contributed talks, poster sessions, and short courses, selected to showcase cutting-edge research in Bayesian statistics. Attendance at the meeting will offer attendees a chance to learn about emerging research topics in Bayesian statistics. In addition, the scientific committee has selected as part of the program multiple talks and posters by junior researchers. This offers junior researchers an opportunity to share their research with an international audience of Bayesian statisticians.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award provided travel support for the 2024 World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis (ISBA), held in Venice, Italy, 1-7 July 2024. This is the largest international meeting of Bayesian statisticians, organized every two years by ISBA.

The goal of this award was to support travel of US-based junior researchers, to allow them to present their research (as either a poster or a short talk) and participate in the world meeting. Twenty-five PhD students at US-based academic institutions were granted a travel award of $800 each. This allowed them to partially offset the cost of attending the meeting. Their attendance provided them with professional and networking opportunities and the ability to attend talks, posters, panel discussions and short courses by leading researchers in the field.

Authors of accepted posters and contributed talks, who were either students or recent graduates, were invited to apply for travel funding via a public call for applications distributed through electronic mailing lists. For awards funded by this NSF grant, we considered current students at US-based institutions, a total of 72 applicants. The recipients were selected by a 6-person subcommittee of the ISBA Scientific Committee, based on the applicants’ accepted talk or poster abstracts.

 


Last Modified: 03/18/2025
Modified by: Sinead Williamson
